question: In React, having different stacking contexts can be complex and cause confusion, in what way can we control stacking contexts which would be a solution?
In React, development goes rapid, synthetic events are built-in, do you know why they are added?

answers.value: It’s just something that comes with React: The React team wanted to reinvent the wheel and be “the” modern framework because they believe the web can do better. They created their own DOM API, with features like: jsx, components, app generator (create-react-app), lifecycles and Synthetic Events
To expand on the default browser event system with custom events the React team came with like onInput or onBrowserClose
They are more performant than default DOM events
They are actually “fake” events to use as mocks in your tests with react testing library (hence “synthetic”)

Synthetic events are a wrapper around native events only used in development to prevent firing native DOM events in development. Synthetic events allows for some features in debugging to which makes it much more easy and efficient

Synthetic events was just the name of a React Amsterdam conference back in 2017 because the conference was in the light of “artificial intelligence” talks with React. As merchandise they also gave away syntethic t-shirts and a blue synthetic React bag, which made the reference

correctAnswers.value: To overcome browser inconsistencies
They are more performant than default DOM events

question: In JS, ensuring code quality is no jest, what are reasons can you give why we should test?

answers.value: It’s a mandatory step to fulfill the needs for a CI/CD pipeline process, before going to production
We do it because It actually is a requirement when working with agile scrum: Each sprint we don’t have to go to production, but we should strive to writing tests to successfully conclude a sprint
It helps increasing your LoC and code coverage, which reflects your activity and shows your commitment and is important for measuring individual performance in the team and the company
It builds confidence in your code because you can run it whenever you make changes in code
It’s just code etiquette we all adhere to, e.g: at casual companies, tests are often not required, but if the company is more corporate, etiquettes like this have to be followed
It is only beneficial when you don’t have manual testers in you team
It’s a way to guide visual impaired developers in codebases and help them get familiar with it
It will probably reduce code maintenance

answers.value: .map creates an array for each element it loops over
.map always creates a new array as return value
.map should always be preferred over for and forEach because .map is immutable
.map can be used on array and array-like (e.g node lists) items
.map is a higher order function used to transform data
.map is a higher order function used to filter items in your array for example
.map is a function google came with
.map doesn’t run when the array is empty
.map mutates the array you are working with
.map returns the data type you return in your callback function e.g: when returning an object, you’ll get an object as result
.map is not a browser standard yet, and has to be babelified
.map and .forEach are the same; it doesn’t really matter what you use

question: In CSS, flexbox has a property flex-shrink, now how does this work, do you think?

answers.value: It specifies the amount of space a flex item can occupy when hitting the built-in browser breakpoint
It allows you to shrink elements with a factor based on the given width / height. If a given element is 100px wide, the default flex-shrink value is 1. When you change it to 2, it will be 200px
It specifies that your container is responsive
It ensures the flex items will shrink until it’s content width
It ensures all flex items will stay on a single line
It specifies how much a flex item will shrink relatively to other flex items
It allows resizing elements on the 2d plane
It allows to shrink the screen size off the users device

answers.value: It is not recommended because it opens a security leak, eval is evil
You don’t use it because it’s a special function used by the JIT compiler to make your JS more performant when it’s runs in the browser

It’s used, but not so much because it makes code less readable. It is only used if code needs to be really performant, like in (older) JS environments where functional programming style is even too heavy
It’s just a function used for regular expressions
It’s a useful function when you want to parse CSS styles in your JavaScript e.g when you don’t use CSS modules. It provides a ready-made object (much like the CSS modules “styles” object)
It’s a function used by build tools and uglifiers to provide the fastest build times and hot module reloads
It’s not recommended because it’s deprecated
It’s only used for older browsers when code is transpiled because JS runs way faster when code is ran in eval

question: In HTML, `<meta>` tags are useful, but which answers listed below are untruthful?
